trial_identification.studytitle: How common is bacteria in the urine of patients with urinary catheters after radical surgery on the prostate for prostate cancer and does it get cleared one week after removing the catheter
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In patients who have had radical prostatectomy for prostate carcinoma, what is the incidence of bacteriuria at the time of urinary catheter removal and does it get cleared 1 week post-removal

conditions.healthcondition: Bacteriuria in patients undergoing radical prostatectomy

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of infection and infectious agents

interventions.interventions: Rate of bacteriuria in patients having radical prostatectomy at time of catheter removal and 1 week post-removal

primaryOutcome.outcome: Rate of bacteriuria at time of catheter removal - assessed with mid-stream urine microscopy and culture
Rate of bacteriuria 1 week post catheter removal - assessed with mid-stream urine microscopy and culture

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: All patients having radical prostatectomy in Hollywood Private Hospital, St John of God Hospital Subiaco & Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Urologist Western Urology 26 McCourt Street Leederville, WA 6007

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: Sir Charles Gairdner Hospital Hospital Avenue Nedlands, WA 6009

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The incidence of bacteria in the urine after radical prostatectomy when patients still have their catheters is not known. How qucikly the bacteria clears after the catheter is removed is also not known. Presence of bacteria is a risk for infection which can increase patient morbidity. We want to investigate the rate of bacteria in the urine before and after catheter removal and the incidence of symptomatic urinary tract infection
